newsitem.title: UK: UK court kills off book pricing pact.
newsitem.headline: UK court kills off book pricing pact.

text.p: A British court sealed the fate on Thursday of a century-old price-fixing agreement between book publishers, allowing continued discounting of top titles.
The Restrictive Practices Court ruled that the so-called Net Book Agreement, which had fallen into disuse, should be regarded as dead and buried.
The Court supported moves by the Office of Fair Trading to scrap the NBA, rejecting arguments to retain it from literary figures including Tom Stoppard and Auberon Waugh.
Judge Mr Justice Ferris said the court was satisfied the NBA restrictions were "contrary to the public interest".
The NBA was a pact under which publishers fixed the price of a title for six months after publication. It effectively ended in 1995 when leading publishers withdrew, saying it was no longer workable.
Their withdrawal allowed high street stores to fight a book price war, with supermarkets getting in on the act by selling cut-price bestsellers on their shelves.
The NBA's defenders argued that its removal would signal the end for many small bookshops and lead to fewer titles being published as margins declined.
